scenes.background: You are leading a project team that has just received an urgent assignment requiring a significant amount of work to be completed within a tight deadline. The team is feeling a lot of pressure, and morale is low, with some members showing signs of frustration and anxiety. One of your team members, Lisa, says: 'I don't think we can meet this deadline. It's just too much work in too little time.' You responded by acknowledging the difficulty and suggesting to prioritize tasks and see if additional resources are needed. As the team begins to break down the tasks, [Monica] seems hesitant and [Bob] looks frustrated. You advised the team to stay focused on what they can control. [Monica] and [Bob] still seem uneasy. You emphasized the importance of focusing on tasks, causing [Monica] to frown and [Bob] to nod with a sarcastic tone. The atmosphere remains tense. You pointed out that complaining won't help and suggested focusing on solutions instead. [Monica] and [Bob] exchange glances, still looking doubtful.
scenes.description: [Monica] raises an eyebrow: 'Solutions? What solutions? We don't even have enough time to think clearly, let alone come up with solutions.' [Bob] chips in, rolling his eyes: 'Yeah, it's like trying to put out a forest fire with a garden hose.'

options.text: Well, we have to start somewhere. Let's brainstorm and see what we can come up with.
options.analysis: You encouraged the team to start brainstorming, showing good emotional detection and social skills, though emotional regulation could be improved.

options.text: I get it, but let's focus on what we can control and take it one step at a time.
options.analysis: You emphasized the importance of focusing on manageable tasks, showing good emotional regulation but could improve on emotional perception and interpersonal balance.

options.text: If anyone has a better idea, now's the time to share it. Otherwise, let's get to work.
options.analysis: You pushed the team to either contribute or focus on the tasks, showing good communication skills, but emotional perception and interpersonal balance could be improved.
